channel.title: New Build
channel.description:
Just complete my new build I've been tempted to buy for about 6 months, finally got round to it. NAS next!
[img]http://i.imgur.com/SqAUOh.jpg[/img]
[img]http://i.imgur.com/YaFEbh.jpg[/img]
Amazed at SSD performance (never used one before), will be stress testing and benchmarking tonight as I plan to start some OCing.
EDIT: Lol forgot specs.
Asus Z77 Sabertooth i7-3770K (H100 Cooler) 16gb Corsair Vengeance 1600mhz GTX 680 4GB FTW+ Edition OCZ Vertex4 SSD HX750w PSU
Case is a Corsair 550D, which I'm very happy with, sound proofing makes this case almost silent and the Dell U2711 is absolutely stunning, can't believe I've been sat on a 17" monitor since 2005 :D
All in all very happy so far, rather expensive but I usually upgrade 5+ years apart so this should last me quite a while.
I did look for the post your build thread but its last few pages were derailed, so seems like its a new topic :|

item.title: New Build
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Beautiful… I’m so jealous.

Read full topic

item.title: New Build
item.dc:creator: @ox_random_xi ox random xi
item.description:
@ox_random_xi wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:17, topic:449076”][quote author=ox random xi link=topic=551973.msg4046983#msg4046983 date=1342163605]

Wow

Eh the 600 series is still a bit too high priced for a graphics card for me. Looking to upgrade from my GTX 560 ti thought and im not sure what will give me the best bang for my buck

I’m planning on picking a GTX 560 ti up soon, would you recommend at all?
(coming from a gt 520 at the moment)
[/quote]
I mean yea its a great card everything is playable, but im addicted to having a solid 60 fps on every game I play, and that was fine back when I have my 1600x900 monitor, I upgraded to a 1900x1080 and it took about 10-12 frames with it. I can still max out games but BF3 is getting to the point where I can’t have HBAO or 4x AA. Skyrim is playable on Ultra but even on Ultra the game looks terrible for its distance LOD. So I wanted to crank up ini files and use mods to improve visible view distance.[/quote]
well, on a gt 520 right now with a 1680 x 1050 I’m running games fine but I thought I could do an upgrade. I’m not used to running fantastic games so I’m not going to be scared haha.

Read full topic

item.title: New Build
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Yeah I don’t think Asus would design something to do the opposite of what its meant to. From what i’ve read removing it can increase temps by 2-3C and with the 35mm accessory fans added it lowers temps another 2-3C. However being so small they run at about 4000-5000rpm and are rather noisy so I have them set to only come on when temps reach 50C.

I’d certainly recommend everything thus far.

Read full topic

It’s the “Thermal Armour” Asus include with some of their Sabertooth boards, supposedly allows better cooling and dust protection. Wasn’t a big plus point of the board but a nice addition.
[/quote]

I think it actually looks pretty good but it seems that it would insulate rather than conduct the heat away[/quote]Heat pipes on the inside.

item.title: New Build
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:15, topic:449076”][quote author=Frell link=topic=551973.msg4046781#msg4046781 date=1342148870]
Wow

Eh the 600 series is still a bit too high priced for a graphics card for me. Looking to upgrade from my GTX 560 ti thought and im not sure what will give me the best bang for my buck
[/quote]
Probably another 560 in SLI? Slightly more powerful than a 580/670 only a lot less $$$.

Sick build, would be exactly what I’d build if I had the cash, PSU wattage is a little small though for a 680 system surely?[/quote]A 680 in a standard gaming system (3930k cpu, 16gb ram, etc) uses at full load about 284W, so no. It’s just a safety margin, and to assure the PSU isn’t on max load, which causes heat and noise.

Read full topic

item.title: New Build
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“ox random xi, post:13, topic:449076”][quote author=Frell link=topic=551973.msg4046781#msg4046781 date=1342148870]
Wow

Eh the 600 series is still a bit too high priced for a graphics card for me. Looking to upgrade from my GTX 560 ti thought and im not sure what will give me the best bang for my buck
[/quote]
I’m planning on picking a GTX 560 ti up soon, would you recommend at all?
(coming from a gt 520 at the moment)[/quote]
I mean yea its a great card everything is playable, but im addicted to having a solid 60 fps on every game I play, and that was fine back when I have my 1600x900 monitor, I upgraded to a 1900x1080 and it took about 10-12 frames with it. I can still max out games but BF3 is getting to the point where I can’t have HBAO or 4x AA. Skyrim is playable on Ultra but even on Ultra the game looks terrible for its distance LOD. So I wanted to crank up ini files and use mods to improve visible view distance.

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:15, topic:449076”][quote author=Frell link=topic=551973.msg4046781#msg4046781 date=1342148870]
Wow

Eh the 600 series is still a bit too high priced for a graphics card for me. Looking to upgrade from my GTX 560 ti thought and im not sure what will give me the best bang for my buck
[/quote]
Probably another 560 in SLI? Slightly more powerful than a 580/670 only a lot less $$$.

Sick build, would be exactly what I’d build if I had the cash, PSU wattage is a little small though for a 680 system surely?[/quote]
Id have to get a new mobo though, and the 560 ti price has only dropped $60 since the 600s came out, Id rather that $240 go towards a new card

Read full topic

item.title: New Build
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Nah, 750W is far above what is needed for a single 680 card, as the minimum requirement Evga specify is 550W (which is probably playing it safe).

item.title: New Build
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Yeah I have been buying parts over a few weeks with a lot of other stuff, so I haven’t sat down and worked out a total price of the PC (I just budgeted for everything I need and kept within that) but using PCPartPicker I can give you a damn good estimate:

http://pcpartpicker.com/uk/p/bOdI

Note that isn’t the 4gb version of the 680, but some of those prices can definitely be beaten if you shop around.

For anyone interested in hardware reviews, I currently have my i7-3770K OCed to 4.5ghz at 1.6v, thats running up temps in the region of 50-60C under high load, which isn’t too bad at all. I reckon I could push for 4.7 or even 5.0 at higher (1.3+) voltage but I’m staying put for now. Stability tests ran for 3 hours with no problems.

I’ll get some benchmark results tonight.

Read full topic

item.title: New Build
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

Case - 140
Board - 240
RAM - 100
CPU - 350
SSD - 220
Graphics - 630
Total - around 1680

Some parts could have been bought cheaper or more expensive, all these prices were taken from newegg and tigerdirect.
